http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/4603961.stm
 
 For those of you who have been watching the evidence unfold lately that birds are the surviving remains of the dinosaur dynasty, it'll come as no surprise that this discovery over how to sex dinosaurs comes from a technique that identifies the bones of female birds.

This is the same team working at the Museum of the Rockies in Bozeman, MT that reportedd the soft tissue remnants from a T. rex recently. This may be the same specimen since they had to cut the femur to move it and this allowed access to the interior.
 
 The Museum of the Rockies is associated with Montana State University, where Jack Horner also teaches. Mary Schweitzer and Jennifer Wittmeyer are from the University of North Carolina where Dr. Schweitzer teaches, although she earned her PhD at Montana State U.
 
 This is another piece of evidence that birds are descended from the theropod dinosaurs. Cladistic analysis indicates that the tyrannosauroids and the maniraptoriformes separated from a common ancestral lineage.

Scientists: Dinosaur bones show T. rex link to birds
 Friday, June 3, 2005 Posted: 1500 GMT (2300 HKT) 
 
 WASHINGTON, June 2 (Reuters) -- A Tyrannosaurus rex dinosaur that died 68 million years ago has provided some of the strongest evidence yet that birds are the closest-living relatives of dinosaurs, scientists said on Thursday.
 
 Soft tissue found in the animal's thighbone strongly suggests it was a female, and just about to lay eggs, the researchers report.
